thread.title_full: CFMEU to pay Boral up to $9 million to reach settlement in "black ban" lawsuit

title: CFMEU to pay Boral up to $9 million to reach settlement in "black ban" lawsuit
text:
Boral and the building union clashed in the wake of separate industrial stoush with Grocon. Photo: Justin McManus
CFMEU to pay Grocon $3.5 million over blockade Australia's biggest construction union has agreed to pay more than $7 million as part of a massive settlement over its alleged "black ban" of concrete giant Boral in central Melbourne.
We have fought long and hard to get to the point where we can start to reclaim our position in the Melbourne CBD
Boral CEO Mike Kane In one of the largest-ever industrial payouts, the powerful Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union will pay Boral between $7 million and $9 million in damages and legal costs, and will enter into a binding agreement that prohibits the union from interfering with Boral's business for a three-year period.
"We've improved Boral's cost base, strengthened the balance sheet and we are managing our portfolio of businesses more efficiently," says Boral CEO Mike Kane. Photo: Peter Braig
Boral had been seeking more than $20 million in damages in the Victorian Supreme Court after claiming to be the victim of a secondary boycott that froze its products out of almost all high-rise work in Melbourne for years.
Advertisement The company alleged the illegal ban began in 2013 after it refused to cede to the CFMEU's demands that it stop supplying developer Grocon, with whom the militant union is engaged in a simmering industrial feud.
Major win CFMEU assistant state secretary John Setka speaks with workers at a Melbourne CBD construction site Friday 10 June 2011 Picture by Craig Abraham The Age Photo: Craig Abraham
Boral chief executive Mike Kane said the agreement was a major win in the effort to "re-establish the rule of law on Melbourne construction sites".
"We will now be protected against illegal interference in serving our customers," he said.
"We have fought long and hard to get to the point where we can start to reclaim our position in the Melbourne CBD and we look forward to working with those customers that have felt unable to do so because of the ban."
Under the deal, the CFMEU will face penalties from $50,000 to $200,000 if it breaches any terms of the agreement and interferes with Boral.
The out-of-court payout comes at a troubling time for the militant CFMEU, which recently settled with Grocon for more than $3.5 million over illegal work site blockades, and faces ongoing legal expenses before the trade union royal commission and multiple federal court lawsuits.
The CFMEU said the agreed damages settlement was for $4 million, plus costs, and Boral's claims that it would cost the union $9 million were untrue.
Union relieved A union spokesman said the result was a humiliation for Boral and Mr Kane, who had "claimed losses of over $23 million".
"Mr Kane's ideological campaign against the union has been damaging Boral's reputation for that entire time," he said.
"Shareholders will be breathing a sigh of relief now Mr Kane will be able to spend more time focusing on the financial future of Boral rather than waging ideological wars against the union movement."
The CFMEU said it hoped the end of the protracted court proceedings would allow Boral to focus on safety rather than "politically motivated litigation".
Boral has been fighting for damages for losses on 16 Melbourne projects, loss in market share and being forced to offer cut-rate concrete prices to entice customers to stay.
Barrister Stuart Wood, for Boral, told the Supreme Court that CFMEU officials had used intimidation and conspiracy tactics to stop Boral's trucks being allowed onto work sites.
He said the company had a 30 per cent market share of inner Melbourne commercial work prior to the secondary boycott beginning in 2013.
But that dropped to 10 per cent as a result of the ban that caused long-time Boral customers to choose other suppliers to avoid industrial strife with the union, the court heard.
Boral examined Boral's credibility was shaken under cross-examination when the company revealed it had estimated the impact of the union-led ban by "counting the number of cranes" visible in Melbourne's CBD and comparing that to its own workload.
CFMEU barrister Rachel Doyle cited company records to argue Boral's market share was closer to 20 per cent in 2008 before falling to 15 per cent in 2012.
Ms Doyle said Boral was affected by prevailing market forces including softening demand, hot competition and downward pressure on prices.
"It's a competitive market where price is king and oppositions ruthlessly target each other's customers," she said.
Boral said Friday's settlement with the CFMEU "breaks new ground" in the resolution of union disputes in Australia by including a rigorous, legally binding regime of controls prohibiting interference with Boral's business.
The CFMEU will publicly commit that its organisers and shop stewards will not interfere with Boral in the delivery of concrete and other services, and will make clear to the market that construction businesses are free to choose their suppliers without fear of retribution, the company said in a statement.
